key: _gpt-5__How does the evidence for using shelterwood harvesting compare with clearcutting for promoting plant diversity and tree regeneration?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Across three replicated, controlled studies in Sweden and the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in higher plant diversity compared with clearcutting.
[Statement 2]: Across three replicated, controlled studies in Sweden and the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in lower grass cover compared with clearcutting.
[Statement 3]: Across three replicated, controlled studies in Sweden and the USA, shelterwood harvesting resulted in a higher density of tree species compared with clearcutting.
[Statement 4]: Six of seven studies in Australia, Iran, Nepal and the USA reported that shelterwood harvesting increased the abundance, species richness and diversity of understory plants.
[Statement 5]: Six of seven studies in Australia, Iran, Nepal and the USA reported that shelterwood harvesting improved growth and survival of young trees.
[Statement 6]: One study found that shelterwood harvesting decreased plant species richness and abundance.
[Statement 7]: One study found that shelterwood harvesting had no effect on tree abundance.
[Statement 8]: One Canadian study found that shelterwood harvesting had no effect on red oak acorn production.

[Statement 1]: Post-fire tree thinning was associated with increased plant species richness in two studies in Spain.
[Statement 2]: Post-fire tree thinning was associated with an increased cover of aspen saplings in Canada.
[Statement 3]: Post-fire tree thinning was associated with decreased plant biomass in the USA.
[Statement 4]: Post-fire tree thinning was associated with decreased mortality of pine seedlings in Israel.
[Statement 5]: Logging after a wildfire decreased species richness and diversity of mosses in a paired-site study in Canada.
[Statement 6]: Post-fire sowing of herbaceous plant seeds in burnt forest areas showed a decreased number and cover of native species in one USA study.
[Statement 7]: Post-fire sowing of herbaceous plant seeds in burnt forest areas showed a decreased density of tree seedlings in another USA study.
[Statement 8]: Post-fire sowing of herbaceous plant seeds in burnt forest areas showed no effect on total plant cover or species richness across three USA studies.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Multiple methods for controlling problematic or invasive plants have been tested across conservation and restoration contexts.
[Statement 2]: Reviews and replicated field trials report that specific management regimes can reduce pernicious weeds.
[Statement 3]: Effective approaches for controlling creeping thistle include cutting, infection with fungal pathogens, and lenient grazing.
[Statement 4]: A non-native beetle biocontrol was unsuitable for controlling creeping thistle due to poor survival of the beetles.
[Statement 5]: The performance of herbicides in controlling invasive plants varied depending on the target species.
[Statement 6]: High-concentration herbicide treatments killed less than half of the targeted broad-leaved dock.
[Statement 7]: A grass-specific herbicide eliminated black grass when applied in winter treatments.
[Statement 8]: Some herbicides, like asulam, negatively affected non-target species such as green dock beetles.
[Statement 9]: In freshwater swamps dominated by invasive canarygrass, adding prescribed fire after herbicide application increased overall diversity relative to using herbicide alone.
[Statement 10]: In freshwater swamps dominated by invasive canarygrass, adding prescribed fire after herbicide application did not increase species richness or native richness.
[Statement 11]: In freshwater swamps dominated by invasive canarygrass, tree seedling density was unaffected by the addition of prescribed fire after herbicide application.
[Statement 12]: In freshwater swamps dominated by invasive canarygrass, mowing before applying herbicide did not change overall richness or diversity compared to using herbicide alone.
[Statement 13]: Multi-action management involving cutting, disking, and herbicide increased non-planted tree seedlings compared to no management.
[Statement 14]: Multi-action management involving cutting, disking, and herbicide maintained the cover of herbs other than canarygrass.
[Statement 15]: Physical disturbance, such as ploughing or disking, after herbicide application increased overall richness and diversity relative to using herbicide alone.
[Statement 16]: Physical disturbance after herbicide application had mixed effects on tree seedlings.
[Statement 17]: Physical disturbance after herbicide application at least maintained non-target herb cover.
[Statement 18]: Physical disturbance after herbicide application affected the abundances of some non-target species.
[Statement 19]: In salt marshes, cutting invading mangrove trees increased the total cover of marsh vegetation when more than half of the trees were removed.
[Statement 20]: Greater shifts in the plant community composition of salt marshes occurred after two years of continual removal of invading mangrove trees.
[Statement 21]: Herbicide use against bracken showed mixed vegetation responses across UK heathland studies.
[Statement 22]: In some trials using herbicide against bracken, there were increases in heather seedlings or biomass, while in other trials, there was no increase in heather cover.
[Statement 23]: Responses of species richness to herbicide use against bracken were inconsistent.
[Statement 24]: The biomass or cover of bracken was often reduced by herbicide, though one study found no change.
[Statement 25]: Following herbicide use against bracken, some non-target species, such as wavy hair-grass and sheep’s fescue, increased in abundance.
[Statement 26]: A replicated field trial showed that combining herbicide application and weeding to control non-native grasses reduced non-native grass cover.
[Statement 27]: A replicated field trial showed that combining herbicide application and weeding to control non-native grasses increased native grass and forb cover.
[Statement 28]: Combining herbicide application and weeding to control non-native grasses did not increase native species richness.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: A review from the USA and Canada argues that education alone was not sufficient to change behaviour.
[Statement 2]: Education could act as a catalytic factor for behaviour change when used alongside economic incentives and law enforcement.
[Statement 3]: Awareness combined with other interventions led to increased numbers of natterjack toads.
[Statement 4]: The combination of awareness campaigns and other interventions resulted in the creation of 1,023 ponds.
[Statement 5]: Education and awareness initiatives were linked to an increased Philippine crocodile population.
[Statement 6]: Education and awareness initiatives were linked to reduced leatherback turtle nest poaching.
[Statement 7]: Education and awareness initiatives were linked to a decrease in the human killing of Philippine crocodiles.
[Statement 8]: Using road signs as an awareness measure resulted in fewer road-deaths of lesser Antillean iguanas.
[Statement 9]: Following education and awareness initiatives, 276 non-venomous snakes were rescued.
[Statement 10]: Multimedia campaigns or the opening of a wildlife education museum, along with other interventions, resulted in 61–138% increases in black howler monkeys over 3–13 years.
[Statement 11]: Education and awareness initiatives improved public attitudes and knowledge about tamarins.
[Statement 12]: The distribution of conservation books in schools led to the cessation of poaching of diademed sifakas and black-and-white ruffed lemurs.
[Statement 13]: Awareness campaigns, when combined with other interventions, increased the hoolock gibbon population by 66% over five years.
[Statement 14]: Education initiatives increased primate knowledge among sanctuary visitors.
[Statement 15]: Messaging campaigns for lowland gorillas successfully reached large audiences.
[Statement 16]: Educating communities about the ecological roles of bats reduced the stated intention to hunt bats.
[Statement 17]: A tourist awareness effort increased knowledge of axolotls but did not necessarily change tourist behaviours.
[Statement 18]: Press conferences that publicized frog conservation had no effect on a green tree frog project.
[Statement 19]: Some education initiatives reached tens of thousands of people without providing direct evidence of behaviour change.
[Statement 20]: Hotel information leaflets did not reduce the number of lights left on at night by guests.

parts.text:

[Statement 2]: Five studies on wire fencing found an increased cover and size of understory plants.
[Statement 3]: Six studies on wire fencing found no effect on understory cover, seed density, species richness or diversity.
[Statement 4]: The effects of wire fencing on young trees varied across studies.
[Statement 5]: One study on wire fencing found increased biomass of young trees.
[Statement 6]: One study on wire fencing found decreased density of young trees.
[Statement 7]: One study on wire fencing found the effects on young trees were mixed by species.
[Statement 8]: Two replicated, controlled USA studies found that wire fencing increased tree density.
[Statement 9]: Evidence from one controlled study in South Africa found that using electric fencing to exclude elephants and nyalas increased tree density.

parts.text:

[Statement 1]: Across studied taxa, logging intensity and technique influence wildlife responses.
[Statement 2]: For bats, reduced-impact/selective logging had smaller effects on bat abundance than conventional logging.
[Statement 3]: A German study found that overall bat activity and diversity were similar between selectively and conventionally logged forests.
[Statement 4]: Bat community composition differed between selectively and conventionally logged forests in Trinidad.
[Statement 5]: Selective logging techniques that opened the canopy increased bat activity at two of three Italian sites.
[Statement 6]: A site comparison in Sierra Leone found higher primate densities in low-intensity logged forests than in high-intensity logged forests.
[Statement 7]: A before-and-after study in Madagascar found that lemur numbers increased after selective logging.
[Statement 8]: A site comparison in Uganda found similar primate densities between low- and high-intensity logged forests.
[Statement 9]: No evidence was found for the effects of clearing open patches on primate populations.
[Statement 10]: No studies were found on the effects of retaining riparian buffer strips during timber harvest on butterflies and moths.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Shelterwood systems, group-selection systems, and broader partial logging approaches are alternatives to clearcutting for timber harvesting.
[Statement 2]: Shelterwood harvesting generally increased understory plant abundance, species richness, and diversity.
[Statement 3]: Shelterwood harvesting generally improved the growth and survival of young trees in most studies.
[Statement 4]: One study reported that shelterwood harvesting decreased plant richness and abundance.
[Statement 5]: One study found shelterwood harvesting had no effect on tree abundance.
[Statement 6]: One study reported no effect from shelterwood harvesting on red oak acorn production.
[Statement 7]: Group-selection harvesting showed mixed outcomes.
[Statement 8]: Several studies found group-selection harvesting increased understory cover and diversity.
[Statement 9]: Several studies found group-selection harvesting led to a higher density of young trees.
[Statement 10]: Other studies reported that group-selection harvesting decreased understory species richness and biomass.
[Statement 11]: Some studies found group-selection harvesting had no effect on richness, diversity, tree density, or growth rate.
[Statement 12]: Across a wider set of partial logging interventions, about half of studies reported increased understory plant density and cover.
[Statement 13]: Across a wider set of partial logging interventions, the remainder of studies showed no or mixed effects on understory plant density and cover.
[Statement 14]: In studies on partial logging interventions, species richness and diversity increased in several studies.
[Statement 15]: In studies on partial logging interventions, other studies found no effect on species richness and diversity.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Excluding livestock from forest sections with wire fences increased understory plant biomass, species richness, density, and cover in some studies.
[Statement 2]: In other studies, excluding livestock from forest sections with wire fences had mixed or no effects on understory plants.
[Statement 3]: The exclusion of livestock also increased the size and density of regenerating trees in several studies.
[Statement 4]: One study found that livestock exclusion decreased tree density without affecting the size of regenerating trees.
[Statement 5]: Preventing livestock grazing increased the survival, species richness, and diversity of understory plants in some studies.
[Statement 6]: In at least one case, preventing livestock grazing had mixed effects on understory plants.
[Statement 7]: Preventing livestock grazing also increased the density of oak seedlings and saplings in a site comparison.
[Statement 8]: Reducing grazing intensity increased the number of tree saplings in the UK.
[Statement 9]: Reducing grazing intensity increased understory biomass in Greece.
[Statement 10]: Shortening the grazing period or controlling the season increased the abundance and size of regenerating oak trees in Spain.
[Statement 11]: Shortening the grazing period or controlling the season showed no effect on native plant species richness in Australia.
[Statement 12]: Shortening the grazing period or controlling the season was associated with higher numbers of tree seedlings following summer grazing compared to winter grazing in the UK.

_gpt-5__What is the state of the evidence for interventions aimed at reducing the risk or impact of forest fires?

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: No evidence was found assessing the effects of using signs to prevent fire on forests.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found evaluating the effects of thinning vegetation to prevent wild fires on peatland vegetation.
[Statement 3]: Of fourteen studies on prescribed fire for amphibians, eight found no effect on amphibian abundance or species numbers.
[Statement 4]: Of fourteen studies on prescribed fire for amphibians, four found mixed effects on amphibian abundance or species numbers depending on the species or time.
[Statement 5]: Of fourteen studies on prescribed fire for amphibians, three found increases in amphibian abundance or species numbers.
[Statement 6]: Of fourteen studies on prescribed fire for amphibians, one found a decrease in amphibian abundance or species numbers.
[Statement 7]: Two studies on prescribed fire for amphibians found that amphibian abundance changed with time since the fire, showing either an increase or a decrease.
[Statement 8]: One before-and-after study found that prescribed fire increased spotted salamander hatching success.
[Statement 9]: Of fifteen studies on the effects of prescribed fire on young trees, five found an increased density or biomass of young trees.
[Statement 10]: Of fifteen studies on the effects of prescribed fire on young trees, two found a decreased density of new trees.
[Statement 11]: Of fifteen studies on the effects of prescribed fire on young trees, eight found no effect or mixed effects depending on the species, location, or fire frequency.
[Statement 12]: Two studies on the effects of prescribed fire on young trees found mixed effects on species diversity.
[Statement 13]: Two studies on the effects of prescribed fire found mixed effects on the survival of young trees.
[Statement 14]: Of twenty-two studies on the effects of prescribed fire on understory plants, eight found increased cover, density, or biomass.
[Statement 15]: Of twenty-two studies on the effects of prescribed fire on understory plants, six found decreased cover.
[Statement 16]: Of twenty-two studies on the effects of prescribed fire on understory plants, eight found no effect or mixed effects.
[Statement 17]: Of twenty-four studies on the effects of prescribed fire on understory plants, fourteen found increased species richness or diversity.
[Statement 18]: Of twenty-four studies on the effects of prescribed fire on understory plants, one found decreased species richness.
[Statement 19]: Of twenty-four studies on the effects of prescribed fire on understory plants, nine found no effect or mixed effects on species richness or diversity.
[Statement 20]: Three of four studies on prescribed fire for butterflies and moths found higher butterfly species richness one to two years after burning.
[Statement 21]: One of four studies on prescribed fire for butterflies and moths found butterfly species richness was similar to unburned areas.
[Statement 22]: Two studies found higher butterfly abundance after burning, which was often combined with thinning.
[Statement 23]: One study reported fewer Eltham copper caterpillars after selective burning.
[Statement 24]: One replicated controlled trial reported that combining cutting and burning was best for bee conservation.
[Statement 25]: One replicated controlled trial reported that combining cutting and burning increased herbaceous plant cover in subsequent years.
[Statement 26]: Three studies found that, compared to prescribed burning, mechanical removal of understorey vegetation did not increase abundances of white-footed mice, shrews, or four other rodent species.
[Statement 27]: One controlled study found higher abundances of three rodent species after the removal of Ashe juniper trees.
[Statement 28]: A before-and-after, site comparison study found increased use of areas by Rocky Mountain bighorn sheep after tree removal.

[Statement 1]: No evidence was found assessing the effects on outcomes of providing legal protection of forests from development.
[Statement 2]: No studies were found that directly and quantitatively tested the effects of providing legal protection of forests from development.
[Statement 3]: Two site-comparison studies in Nigeria and Iran found legal protection of forests increased tree species richness and diversity.
[Statement 4]: Two site-comparison studies in Nigeria and Iran found legal protection of forests increased the density of young trees.
[Statement 5]: One replicated, paired-site study in Mexico found legal protection of forests had no effect on the seed density and diversity of trees and shrubs.
[Statement 6]: Four studies from Europe reported population increases or more positive population trends in protected habitats.
[Statement 7]: A literature review in China reported that many cranes used nature reserves.
[Statement 8]: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in Argentina found some bird guilds had higher species richness or higher densities in protected forests.
[Statement 9]: A replicated, randomized, controlled study in Argentina found some bird guilds showed no differences in species richness or densities in protected forests.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: Four studies from Europe reported population increases following habitat protection.

[Statement 6]: A replicated, randomised, controlled study in Argentina found some bird guilds had higher densities in protected forests.

parts.text:
[Statement 1]: In Ethiopia and Nepal, forest cover increased more in community-managed forests than in forests not managed by local communities.
[Statement 2]: In Colombia, deforestation rates in community-managed forests did not differ from rates in forests not managed by local communities or in uninhabited national parks.
[Statement 3]: In Pakistan, involving local communities with park management was associated with an increasing population of Himalayan brown bears.
[Statement 4]: In Namibia, fewer farmers in community-based conservancies removed large carnivores than non-conservancy members.
[Statement 5]: In Belize, black howler monkeys increased by 138% over 13 years after local communities received monetary benefits, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 6]: In the Republic of Congo, most reintroduced central chimpanzees survived over five years where local communities received monetary benefits, alongside other interventions.
[Statement 7]: In Rwanda, Uganda and the Democratic Republic of Congo, mountain gorilla numbers declined by 28% over 41 years despite development projects in nearby communities, alongside other interventions.
